childMarkdownRemark.html:
Dog Anxiety - Definition

Anxiety in a dog is defined as the anticipation of potential dangers from unknown sources.

Dog Anxiety - Causes

Most common triggers for anxiety in dogs are:

  • Fear - caused by loud noises; unfamiliar people or animals; visual stimuli like hats, trench coats, umbrellas, etc.; new or different environments; specific situations like the vet, car rides, elevators, etc.; unfamiliar surfaces like grass, wood floors, grills, etc.
  • Separation - caused by the discomfort that the dog feels when he id left alone
  • Illness or Injury - caused by pain, infections, toxicity.
  • Age-related - caused by similar signs as in human Alzheimer's disease: loss of memory, awareness, perception.

Dog Anxiety - Symptoms

Most of the times, the dog will develop behavioural problems and/, or he will depict bodily reactions that are causing his panic, anxiety and fear.

Examples of severe anxiety symptoms:

  • aggression
  • drooling
  • urinating or defecating in the house, also emptying of the anal glands
  • panic
  • destruction
  • excessive barking and howling
  • pacing and restlessness
  • repetitive or compulsive behaviours

Examples of subtle anxiety symptoms:

  • seeking extra comfort or affection
  • excessive licking or chewing
  • hiding or searching for solitude
  • panting and shaking

Dog Anxiety - Manifestation

One of the most common symptoms is aggression. There are two types of aggressive behaviour: direct and indirect.

Dog behaviourists speak about direct aggression when a dog acts aggressively towards another animal or human.

Indirect aggression happens when a person comes between the dog and the source of the dog's aggression, such as another dog.

Another common symptom is destruction. This form of anxiety manifestation can lead to costly repairs but unfortunately, can also lead to the dog injuring himself. The dog will concentrate his destructive behaviour around exit points: doors and windows.

Dog Anxiety - Treatment

First of all, take your puppy to a vet and check him out thoroughly. Do a full blood check and talk to your vet about your dog's symptoms.

I strongly recommend visiting the vet before giving your dog supplements, oils or any medication to treat anxiety.

If the vet clears your dog, then you can consider searching for a dog behaviourist and trainer that will help you with your dog's anxiety.

You might think like: "so I read all this for a "go to a specialist." advice?"

Well yes and no. You now know much more about anxiety and might even know the reasons. But do not underestimate the great help a specialist can provide. They work day after day with issues in dogs. So they have a big backpack full of knowledge and tools.

There are also training methods you can test by yourself, although.

Counterconditioning and Desensitisation Training

Counterconditioning is a training method used to change your dog's response to the stimulus responsible for anxiety, and replacing the anxious behaviour with a more desirable behaviour, like sitting or focusing on the owner. Meaning once your dog has been exposed to the trigger, you train your dog to provide another response to it as before. Praise like there is no other best treat on this planet.

Through desensitization, you slowly introduce your dog to the source of anxiety, preferably in minimal doses and at a decreased intensity.

Repeated exposure and rewarding positive behaviour can help your dog toward managing anxiety, and you also allow your dog to make choices.

Desensitization can be an effective method when your dog's anxiety is brought on by a particular trigger like a firework, thunderstorm, car rides, etc.

Through repeated exposure and rewarding positive behaviour, your dog will learn to reduce his anxious response to the particular trigger.

A common mistake that will actually do more harm than help your dog is to try to comfort your dog. This actually makes it worse, because your dog will think you are rewarding him for the anxious behaviour. Instead of comforting your dog, encourage him to act calmly.

Dog Anxiety - Prevention

Learn Anxious Dog Body Language

To avoid negative experiences for you and your dog, you need to watch and learn your dog's body language. A dog's body will tell you very early what is going on with him.

Knowing your dog's body language will also help you during counterconditioning, and desensitisation training. It will allow you to reinforce that desired positive behaviour.

Socialise Your Puppy

Best way to avoid anxious behaviour is to socialise your puppy very early. Let him know people, animals, places, cars, trams, trains, trucks, fireworks, etc.

Obedience Training

Obedience training is the foundation for an excellent human-dog bond, providing trust and a healthy relationship between the parties.

Obedience is a crucial tool for managing and even preventing anxiety in your dog.

Exercise and Food

Provide your puppy with healthy and dog-friendly food and treats. This will keep your dog healthy.

Exercise is crucial for the dog‚Äôs bodily and mental health. Go on that walk, even if you are later home as expected, play with your dog, cuddle. Do not ignore or neglect him since this will lead to anxious behaviour.

Avoid

And if you find yourself in a situation that you know for sure will escalate, then your best friend is avoidance. Turn around, go into the field, cross the street, avoid dog parks, etc.

Dog Anxiety On Walk

I will cover in this part, mainly the so-called line aggression since this is one of the most known anxiety out there at the moment.

Make peace with the fact that you will make mistakes, your dog will make mistakes, you will be frustrated, at a verge of giving up and scream and run. I have been there. I was sad, angry, terrified and felt like nothing works and helps overcome the line aggression.

My rescue was a knowledgeable trainer that had a genuine experience with fearful dogs. How did I know he will help? It just felt right.

He never suggested anything that hurt my dog, he told me honestly what might change and might not, also said to me that part of the problem is my fault and he showed me what I did wrong and how to do it right.

Knowledge Makes You and Your Dog Happy! Furry Canine Team

postDescription.postDescription: How do you recognize if your dog is anxious on walks? Is your dog pulling on the leash, jumping, barking and looks and sounds aggressive? Let us first dive into the theoretical part of anxiety in dogs to fully understand what anxious dog behaviour is. The second part will give you hands-on dog behaviour training to help you help your dog overcome anxiety.

contentfulBlogPost.postTitle: My Dog Is Anxious On Walks - The Theoretical Part
